p: Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus) was identified in 30–50% of bacterial pneumonia cases in developing countries in the 1990s, followed by Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib; 10–30% of cases), then Staphylococcus aureus and Klebsiella pneumoniae [ 28]. Non-typable H. influenzae (NTHI), and non-typhoid Salmonella spp. have also been implicated in some but not all studies. Other organisms, such as Mycoplasma pneumoniae, Chlamydia spp., Pseudomonas spp. and Escherichia coli also can cause pneumonia. The most common syndromes associated with M. pneumoniae infections are acute bronchitis, pharyngitis and otitis, but 10% of infected children develop pneumonia [ 39].
